metadata.description: Manually curated verified isomorphisms from Sessions 38-57
metadata.methodology: LLM extraction + semantic embeddings (384-dim) + manual curation
metadata.selection_criteria: All excellent + all good discoveries from manual curation

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both describe cell size feedback control through phase-specific mechanisms (sizer/timer/adder). Extrinsic (population-density) vs intrinsic (size-deviation) feedback loops. Trade-offs between control strategies. Perfect structural isomorphism across different cell types.

paper_1.title: Effects of multi-phase control mechanism on fibroblast dynamics
paper_1.mechanism: Cell size determined by control mechanisms across cell cycle phases (sizer, timer, adder strategies). Division kernel and phase-specific control govern size distribution. Population-density-dependent regulation limits total cell numbers (extrinsic feedback). Cell-size-dependent regulation suppresses size variability (intrinsic feedback). Trade-off between extrinsic and intrinsic control.

paper_2.title: Coarse-graining and stochastic oscillations in cell-size homeostasis
paper_2.mechanism: Cell size feedback operates through size deviations (difference between absolute size and cell-cycle progression). Feedback from size to growth rate and cycle timing creates coupled dynamics. In linear regime, dynamics reduce to stochastically forced harmonic oscillator. Cell-cycle timing and intrinsic fluctuations jointly shape size control strategy. Mechanistic feedback structure may differ from apparent coarse-grained correlations due to noise integration.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both describe size homeostasis through feedback. Extrinsic noise and population structure jointly determine size distributions. Noise integration and control strategies. Same mechanism as #1 but different organisms (fibroblasts vs bacteria).

paper_1.title: Effects of multi-phase control mechanism on fibroblast dynamics
paper_1.mechanism: Cell size determined by control mechanisms across cell cycle phases (sizer, timer, adder strategies). Division kernel and phase-specific control govern size distribution. Population-density-dependent regulation limits total cell numbers (extrinsic feedback). Cell-size-dependent regulation suppresses size variability (intrinsic feedback). Trade-off between extrinsic and intrinsic control.

paper_2.title: Cell size control in bacteria
paper_2.mechanism: Cell size fluctuates due to noisy growth rates and size-dependent division noise. Size homeostasis mechanisms compensate for fluctuations through size control strategies. Population dynamics alter size distributions compared to single lineages - exponential population growth changes the effective size control measured in constant-volume experiments. Extrinsic growth noise and population structure jointly determine observed size distributions.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Network position determines productivity through strategic complementarities. Central nodes access diverse knowledge/connections. Preferential attachment reinforces centrality advantage. Isomorphism: innovation networks (Sweden) vs science/tech networks.

paper_1.title: Collaboration for the Bioeconomy -- Evidence from Innovation Output in Sweden
paper_1.mechanism: Firms collaborate forming innovation network. Central firms access diverse knowledge from multiple partners enhancing innovation output. Peripheral firms limited by fewer connections. Network structure (centrality) determines innovation capacity. Successful innovators attract more partners (preferential attachment) reinforcing centrality advantage.

paper_2.title: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks
paper_2.mechanism: An agent's position in a collaboration network determines their productivity. Higher network centrality increases output through strategic complementarities with connected agents. Activity in one domain (scientific) enhances productivity in another domain (technological), but this effect is asymmetric - the reverse direction shows no detectable influence.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both about cell size control but through different mechanisms. Paper 1: feedback across phases. Paper 2: proliferation-driven variability vs mechanical relaxation. Related but not perfect structural match.

paper_1.title: Effects of multi-phase control mechanism on fibroblast dynamics
paper_1.mechanism: Cell size determined by control mechanisms across cell cycle phases (sizer, timer, adder strategies). Division kernel and phase-specific control govern size distribution. Population-density-dependent regulation limits total cell numbers (extrinsic feedback). Cell-size-dependent regulation suppresses size variability (intrinsic feedback). Trade-off between extrinsic and intrinsic control.

paper_2.title: Cell proliferation maintains cell area polydispersity in the growing fruit fly wing epithelium
paper_2.mechanism: Cell proliferation generates area variability while mechanical forces regulate packing. Cell division creates size asymmetry between daughter cells. Mechanical constraints from neighbors limit expansion. Area polydispersity emerges from balance between proliferation-driven variability and mechanical relaxation. Cell-cell adhesion and cortical tension determine equilibrium distributions.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both describe positive Lyapunov exponents (sensitivity to initial conditions), scaling laws, and self-similarity. One in discrete dynamical systems with fractal attractors, one in black hole particle motion. Solid structural match.

paper_1.title: Discrete dynamical systems with scaling and inversion symmetries
paper_1.mechanism: System state evolves discretely through iterated function. Scaling symmetry preserves dynamics under magnification/contraction. Near fixed points, small perturbations grow exponentially (positive Lyapunov exponent) causing sensitive dependence. Trajectories confined to fractal attractor with non-integer dimension. Chaotic regime characterized by scaling laws and self-similarity across scales.

paper_2.title: Chaotic Dynamics in Black Holes
paper_2.mechanism: Particle motion in extremal configurations exhibits positive Lyapunov exponents indicating sensitivity to initial conditions. Chaos persists even at zero temperature. System parameters (spin, charge) modulate chaos strength - increasing one parameter strengthens chaotic behavior while the other weakens it.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Cooperation shaped by behavioral feedback AND resource constraints. Strategic behavior creates reputation/norms while simultaneously affecting shared resources. Feedback between social dynamics and ecological/environmental state. Perfect two-layer coupling.

paper_1.title: Human-AI Cooperation in Public Goods Game
paper_1.mechanism: Reciprocal group dynamics and behavioral inertia drive cooperation levels in groups. Cooperation depends on observed group behavior patterns rather than the identity of participants. These normative mechanisms operate identically regardless of agent type, creating stable cooperation patterns through behavioral feedback.

paper_2.title: Indirect Reciprocity with Environmental Feedback
paper_2.mechanism: Individual behaviors shape reputation through social norms while simultaneously affecting collective resource levels. Environmental changes alter payoff structures, creating feedback between strategic behavior and resource dynamics. Reputation-based cooperation interacts with ecological constraints - cooperative behaviors deplete or enhance shared resources, which then reshape the incentives for future cooperation.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both involve scaling laws and critical behavior. Paper 1: fractal attractors and self-similarity. Paper 2: critical slowing down at bifurcations with diverging timescales. Related mathematical structures.

paper_1.title: Discrete dynamical systems with scaling and inversion symmetries
paper_1.mechanism: System state evolves discretely through iterated function. Scaling symmetry preserves dynamics under magnification/contraction. Near fixed points, small perturbations grow exponentially (positive Lyapunov exponent) causing sensitive dependence. Trajectories confined to fractal attractor with non-integer dimension. Chaotic regime characterized by scaling laws and self-similarity across scales.

paper_2.title: Critical Slowing Down at Bifurcations
paper_2.mechanism: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both about R&D/innovation networks. Network centrality → innovation output. Strategic interactions (Paper 2 adds Stackelberg/Nash equilibrium). Spillovers through connections. Solid match but Paper 1 more specific.

paper_1.title: Collaboration for the Bioeconomy -- Evidence from Innovation Output in Sweden
paper_1.mechanism: Firms collaborate forming innovation network. Central firms access diverse knowledge from multiple partners enhancing innovation output. Peripheral firms limited by fewer connections. Network structure (centrality) determines innovation capacity. Successful innovators attract more partners (preferential attachment) reinforcing centrality advantage.

paper_2.title: R&D Spillovers and Regional Innovation
paper_2.mechanism: R&D spillovers from one entity enhance innovation in neighboring entities. Strategic interactions follow Stackelberg dynamics where leaders and followers reach Nash equilibrium. Highly-qualified employment amplifies spillover effects, creating synergies between different types of R&D investment and regional innovation output.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Free-rider problem with multi-stability and hysteresis (shared resource cleaning) vs cooperation-epidemic coevolution with structural heterogeneity. Both show: heterogeneity as double-edged (creates leverage points AND weak links), multi-stability, and strategic trade-offs between local/global incentives. Beautiful isomorphism!

paper_1.title: Free-Rider Problem in Shared Resources
paper_1.mechanism: Shared resource use creates a cooperation dilemma with cleaning costs, contamination risk, and social incentives forming competing pressures. Cleaning cost primarily determines stability of altruistic behavior. The system exhibits multi-stability and hysteresis - small parameter changes can cause abrupt shifts between cooperation and free-riding equilibria.

paper_2.title: The impact of heterogeneity on the co-evolution of cooperation and epidemics
paper_2.mechanism: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Shock propagation through networks. Network topology determines cascade extent. DeFi contagion vs physical network damage. Seed node position critical in both. Solid structural match.

paper_1.title: DeFi Credit Exposures and Contagion
paper_1.mechanism: Token-mediated dependencies create dense inter-component connections. A shock to one component propagates through dependency links causing contagion effects. Network topology and link weights determine the extent and path of cascading failures across the system.

paper_2.title: Seed Node Position and Network Damage
paper_2.mechanism: Localized damage initiates at a seed node and propagates to neighbors. The structural position of the seed node (local connectivity and topology) amplifies or dampens damage progression. Cumulative link severing during attack progression depends critically on seed node characteristics rather than average network properties.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both show: heterogeneity enables coexistence (homogeneous → marginal/unstable). Spatial structure + network topology govern dynamics. Paper 2 adds high-dimensional chaos. Related but not perfect match.

paper_1.title: Habitat Heterogeneity and Metacommunity Dynamics
paper_1.mechanism: Spatial structure and dispersal networks jointly determine species persistence. Heterogeneous habitats support stable coexistence only above a critical heterogeneity threshold. Homogeneous environments allow coexistence only in a fine-tuned marginal state, creating instability. Network topology encodes dispersal effectiveness through an effective kernel.

paper_2.title: Cross-feeding yields high-dimensional chaos and coexistence of species
paper_2.mechanism: Species cross-feed through metabolite leakage and uptake. Competitive uptake of leaked chemicals creates coupled population-chemical dynamics. Network structure determines attractor types: fixed points, limit cycles, low-dimensional chaos, or high-dimensional chaos. High-dimensional chaos enables coexistence beyond competitive exclusion limits through intermittent switching among quasi-stationary states. Chemical dynamics explore high-dimensional space while populations switch intermittently.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Coevolution of network structure and node attributes. Feedback loop: attributes affect connections, connections affect attributes. Individual cognitive structure (semantic overlap) vs opinion distance. Network-level redundancy emerges. Perfect structural isomorphism!

paper_1.title: Semantic Memory to Collective Creativity
paper_1.mechanism: Individual semantic network topology determines ideational breadth. When agents exchange ideation traces, lower initial overlap predicts larger stimulation gains. Shared inspiration sources create network-level redundancy, forming feedback between individual cognitive structure and collective outcomes.

paper_2.title: Emergent structures in coupled opinion and network dynamics
paper_2.mechanism: Individuals' opinions and network edge weights coevolve through coupled dynamics. Interaction strength depends on opinion distance. Similar opinions strengthen network connections. Connection strength amplifies opinion influence. This creates feedback between opinion convergence and network structure formation. Interaction function form determines emergent structures and stability.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Network position determines output. Strategic complementarities through connections. Lower initial overlap → larger gains (Paper 2) mirrors centrality advantage (Paper 1). Both show feedback between individual structure and collective outcomes. Perfect match!

paper_1.title: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks
paper_1.mechanism: An agent's position in a collaboration network determines their productivity. Higher network centrality increases output through strategic complementarities with connected agents. Activity in one domain (scientific) enhances productivity in another domain (technological), but this effect is asymmetric - the reverse direction shows no detectable influence.

paper_2.title: Semantic Memory to Collective Creativity
paper_2.mechanism: Individual semantic network topology determines ideational breadth. When agents exchange ideation traces, lower initial overlap predicts larger stimulation gains. Shared inspiration sources create network-level redundancy, forming feedback between individual cognitive structure and collective outcomes.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both about spatial structure enabling persistence. Facilitation-competition balance creates threshold dynamics (Allee effect) vs heterogeneity threshold for coexistence. Related mechanisms but different flavors.

paper_1.title: Intermittent precipitation and spatial Allee effects drive irregular vegetation patterns
paper_1.mechanism: Plants facilitate neighboring growth through local resource modification. Facilitation competes with resource competition. When precipitation is intermittent, facilitation-competition balance creates spatial vegetation patterns. Below threshold density, vegetation collapses due to weakened facilitation (spatial Allee effect).

paper_2.title: Habitat Heterogeneity and Metacommunity Dynamics
paper_2.mechanism: Spatial structure and dispersal networks jointly determine species persistence. Heterogeneous habitats support stable coexistence only above a critical heterogeneity threshold. Homogeneous environments allow coexistence only in a fine-tuned marginal state, creating instability. Network topology encodes dispersal effectiveness through an effective kernel.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Network centrality → productivity through strategic complementarities vs cooperation-epidemic coevolution with heterogeneity. Both show heterogeneity affects strategic behavior but mechanisms differ.

paper_1.title: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks
paper_1.mechanism: An agent's position in a collaboration network determines their productivity. Higher network centrality increases output through strategic complementarities with connected agents. Activity in one domain (scientific) enhances productivity in another domain (technological), but this effect is asymmetric - the reverse direction shows no detectable influence.

paper_2.title: The impact of heterogeneity on the co-evolution of cooperation and epidemics
paper_2.mechanism: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Network-mediated competitive pressures. Peer comparison affects strategic behavior. Heterogeneity creates asymmetries. Related but Paper 1 more financial, Paper 2 more epidemiological.

paper_1.title: Mean-Field Price Formation with Network of Relative Performance Concerns
paper_1.mechanism: Agents care about their performance relative to connected peers. Relative performance concerns create strategic interdependencies through network links. Risk-taking behavior adjusts based on peer comparisons. Network topology determines how competitive pressures propagate. This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.

paper_2.title: The impact of heterogeneity on the co-evolution of cooperation and epidemics
paper_2.mechanism: Cooperation and disease transmission coevolve through network structure. Structural heterogeneity creates leverage points - highly connected hubs adopt protection due to amplified risk, catalyzing cooperation. Cost heterogeneity creates weakest links - low-risk individuals free-ride and act as disease reservoirs, undermining cooperation. Heterogeneity is double-edged: influence asymmetry facilitates cooperation, motivation asymmetry degrades it.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Network position → productivity/influence through strategic interactions. Coevolution of attributes and network structure. Similar to #15 but less clear in Paper 1.

Connection strength amplifies opinion influence. This creates feedback between opinion convergence and network structure formation. Interaction function form determines emergent structures and stability.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Network externalities in technology adoption vs innovation networks. Preferential attachment and network topology determine outcomes. Strategic complementarities through connections.

Peripheral firms limited by fewer connections. Network structure (centrality) determines innovation capacity. Successful innovators attract more partners (preferential attachment) reinforcing centrality advantage.

paper_2.title: Technology Adoption and Network Externalities in Financial Systems
paper_2.mechanism: Technology adoption spreads through spatial and network channels. Spatial spillovers and network externalities interact multiplicatively - nearby adoption and connected peer adoption amplify each other. Cumulative adoption pressure accumulates along stochastic paths through spatial-network space. Network position amplifies or dampens spatial effects, creating non-linear adoption dynamics.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both show cooperation coevolving with environmental/network constraints. Feedback between strategic behavior and external state. Paper 1: reputation+resources. Paper 2: cooperation+epidemic. Similar structure.

paper_1.title: Strategic Interactions in Science and Technology Networks
paper_1.mechanism: An agent's position in a collaboration network determines their productivity. Higher network centrality increases output through strategic complementarities with connected agents. Activity in one domain (scientific) enhances productivity in another domain (technological), but this effect is asymmetric - the reverse direction shows no detectable influence.

paper_2.title: Threshold Resource Redistribution in Kinship Networks
paper_2.mechanism: When agents fall below a resource threshold, they solicit resources from connected neighbors based on relatedness. Redistribution creates feedback between kinship network structure and reproduction ability. This enables population survival at lower resource densities but increases network heterogeneity and local centralization.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Network-based cooperation with thresholds. Resource redistribution in kinship networks vs cooperation-epidemic coevolution with heterogeneity as leverage/weak-link.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Network-mediated shock/event propagation. Contagion through dependency links vs extreme event suppression through drive. Both show network topology affects system-wide dynamics.

paper_1.title: DeFi Credit Exposures and Contagion
paper_1.mechanism: Token-mediated dependencies create dense inter-component connections. A shock to one component propagates through dependency links causing contagion effects. Network topology and link weights determine the extent and path of cascading failures across the system.

paper_2.title: Controlling Extreme Events in Networks
paper_2.mechanism: A single driving signal applied to one network component suppresses extreme events throughout the system. In coupled components, drive breaks phase-locking between elements. In networked systems, drive disrupts protoevent frequency dynamics causing frequency decoupling that prevents extreme event cascades.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Cooperation dilemmas with network structure. Public goods reciprocity vs threshold-based resource redistribution. Both involve cooperative behavior shaped by social connections.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Heterogeneous thresholds + decentralized coordination across groups (division of labor) vs information diversity through group sampling (structure-aware updates). Both use threshold heterogeneity + group-level information aggregation to enable collective decision-making.

paper_1.title: Division of labor enables efficient collective decision-making under uncertainty
paper_1.mechanism: Decentralized collective decision-making through heterogeneous threshold-based strategies. Small subset of agents explores continuously (low threshold for action) while majority remains idle until expected reward exceeds threshold (high threshold). Information sharing across group enables synchronized action by majority when conditions improve. Optimal explorer fraction scales sublinearly with group size due to information redundancy. Ecological pressure (cost/reward ratio) modulates heterogeneity: intermediate pressure maximizes diversity, extreme conditions favor homogeneity. No central coordination required - group-level policy emerges from individual threshold rules.

paper_2.title: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks
paper_2.mechanism: Agent strategy updating through structure-aware sampling: number of groups sampled and number of peers consulted within each group jointly determine information diversity. Higher information diversity across groups promotes cooperation in multiplayer dilemmas. Update rules interact with group structure (hypergraph topology): sampling more groups increases cross-group information flow, sampling more peers within groups increases within-group consensus. Weak selection regime reveals analytical threshold for cooperation success as function of information diversity metric. Design principle: diversify information sources across groups to enhance cooperation.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Structure-aware sampling (group-level information diversity) promotes cooperation in multiplayer dilemmas vs network opacity traps agents in echo chambers competing against hallucinated peers. Both use information sampling structure to shape collective strategic outcomes.

paper_1.title: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks
paper_1.mechanism: Agent strategy updating through structure-aware sampling: number of groups sampled and number of peers consulted within each group jointly determine information diversity. Higher information diversity across groups promotes cooperation in multiplayer dilemmas. Update rules interact with group structure (hypergraph topology): sampling more groups increases cross-group information flow, sampling more peers within groups increases within-group consensus. Weak selection regime reveals analytical threshold for cooperation success as function of information diversity metric. Design principle: diversify information sources across groups to enhance cooperation.

paper_2.title: The Architecture of Illusion: Network Opacity
paper_2.mechanism: Escalation principle in strategic complements: Restricting information (reducing network transparency p) traps agents in echo chambers where they compete against hallucinated high-sophistication peers. In games of strategic complements, opacity maximizes aggregate effort by preventing agents from coordinating on low-effort equilibrium. Conversely, transparency required in coordination games to minimize variance. Network topology functions as cognitive zoom lens.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Relative performance concerns create strategic interdependencies through network links; peer comparisons drive behavior vs opacity induces sophisticated bias where agents overestimate opponent depth based on local sample. Network structure biases perception and strategy in both.

paper_1.title: Mean-Field Price Formation with Network of Relative Performance Concerns
paper_1.mechanism: Agents care about their performance relative to connected peers. Relative performance concerns create strategic interdependencies through network links. Risk-taking behavior adjusts based on peer comparisons. Network topology determines how competitive pressures propagate. This peer comparison mechanism affects equilibrium asset prices through aggregated strategic adjustments.

paper_2.title: The Architecture of Illusion: Network Opacity
paper_2.mechanism: Escalation principle in strategic complements: Restricting information (reducing network transparency p) traps agents in echo chambers where they compete against hallucinated high-sophistication peers. In games of strategic complements, opacity maximizes aggregate effort by preventing agents from coordinating on low-effort equilibrium. Conversely, transparency required in coordination games to minimize variance. Network topology functions as cognitive zoom lens.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Spatial spillovers and network externalities amplify each other multiplicatively; cumulative pressure accumulates along paths vs local cohesion-seeking rewires ego networks (decreasing context overlap, increasing mobility), causing global fragmentation. Both demonstrate unintended collective outcomes from individual-level dynamics on spatial-network structures.

paper_1.title: Technology Adoption and Network Externalities in Financial Systems
paper_1.mechanism: Technology adoption spreads through spatial and network channels. Spatial spillovers and network externalities interact multiplicatively - nearby adoption and connected peer adoption amplify each other. Cumulative adoption pressure accumulates along stochastic paths through spatial-network space. Network position amplifies or dampens spatial effects, creating non-linear adoption dynamics.

paper_2.title: Fragmentation of longitudinal social network
paper_2.mechanism: Local cohesion-seeking yields global fragmentation: Social cohesion (average closure) declines >15% over 12 years despite no demographic compositional change. Decline due to rewiring in individual ego networks—decreasing overlap of social contexts, greater geographical mobility. Residential relocation temporarily increases local closure, but causes global network fragmentation. Demonstrates unintended collective consequence: individual-level cohesion-seeking behavior fragments population-scale structure.

paper_1.title: Critical Slowing Down at Bifurcations
paper_1.mechanism: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.

paper_2.title: Heterogeneity dominates irreversibility in random Markov models
paper_2.mechanism: Markov dynamics combine heterogeneity and asymmetry (broken detailed balance). Heterogeneity parameter controls transition rate variability. Asymmetry parameter controls forward-backward correlation. Critical locus emerges where relaxation times diverge. Entropy production and predictive information depend strongly on heterogeneity but weakly on asymmetry. Near criticality, small heterogeneity changes cause large dynamical shifts.

paper_1.title: From Discrete to Continuous Mixed Populations of Conformists, Nonconformists, and Imitators
paper_1.mechanism: Three behavioral types interact: conformists benefit from choosing common strategies, nonconformists profit from rare strategies, and imitators copy highest earners. Population proportions fluctuate in finite populations but equilibrate as population size increases. Strategy proportions undergo perpetual oscillations in small populations, but fluctuation amplitudes approach zero in large populations through stochastic averaging.

paper_2.title: FinEvo: From Isolated Backtests to Ecological Market Games for Multi-Agent Financial Strategy Evolution
paper_2.mechanism: Strategy distributions evolve through selection (performance-based survival), innovation (mutation), and environmental perturbation (external shocks). Individual agents adapt using local signals while population composition shifts based on relative fitness. Two-layer adaptation - individual learning plus population-level evolution - determines whether strategies persist, collapse, or form coalitions.

paper_1.title: Critical Slowing Down at Bifurcations
paper_1.mechanism: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.

paper_2.title: Emergence of Superintelligence from Critical Dynamics
paper_2.mechanism: Qualitative phase transition via spectral condensation at criticality. Progressive reentrant coupling drives system toward infrared critical regime where extensive band of slow collective modes emerges (spectral condensation), reorganizing dynamics qualitatively. Creates emergent capabilities absent at subcritical regime - transition in kind not degree, regardless of system scale.

paper_1.title: Technology Adoption and Network Externalities in Financial Systems
paper_1.mechanism: Technology adoption spreads through spatial and network channels. Spatial spillovers and network externalities interact multiplicatively - nearby adoption and connected peer adoption amplify each other. Cumulative adoption pressure accumulates along stochastic paths through spatial-network space. Network position amplifies or dampens spatial effects, creating non-linear adoption dynamics.

paper_2.title: Structure-aware imitation dynamics on higher-order networks
paper_2.mechanism: Higher-order network structure (beyond pairwise) shapes imitation dynamics through group-dependent adoption rates. Information diversity achieved through structured sampling from local neighborhoods. Adoption probability depends on group composition and size, not just neighbor count. Network hypergraph structure determines equilibrium strategy distributions through sampling bias.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both describe transfer learning across related but distinct domains by separating shared vs domain-specific components. Mechanism 1 uses explicit disentanglement (domain-invariant + domain-specific features) with mutual information optimization. Mechanism 2 uses structured graph representations to identify shared principles. Structural match around the problem: leverage commonalities for transfer while preserving domain-specific distinctiveness.

paper_1.title: Untitled
paper_1.mechanism: Feature disentanglement into domain-invariant and domain-specific components mitigates negative transfer in multi-dataset training. Cross-attention fusion adaptively models component interactions. Mutual information optimization maximizes domain-invariant consistency while minimizing domain-specific redundancy. Complementary shared-private representations enable knowledge transfer while preserving dataset-specific discriminability.

paper_2.title: Untitled
paper_2.mechanism: Transfer learning with structured graph representations enables few-shot adaptation across related domains by identifying shared interaction principles from well-studied systems and rapidly adapting to new contexts with minimal training data.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both describe world models that learn action-conditioned prediction for control. Mechanism 1 focuses on in-context learning of flexible bindings (objects ↔ locations) through sequential prediction. Mechanism 2 focuses on transfer from human video to robot control via latent action representations. Structural match: action-conditioned prediction as substrate for world modeling that enables planning and control through learned dynamics.

paper_1.title: Untitled
paper_1.mechanism: Action-conditioned sequential prediction enables path integration and dynamic object-location binding for world modeling. Prediction accuracy improves across sequence through in-context learning. Structured representations with flexible binding emerge to support prediction - new bindings learnable late in sequence, out-of-distribution bindings acquirable through sequential exposure.

paper_2.title: Untitled
paper_2.mechanism: Continuous latent actions serve as unified proxy actions, enabling interaction knowledge transfer from unlabeled human videos to robot control. World model learns diverse interactions from 44k hours of egocentric video. Post-training on small-scale robot data yields physics understanding and precise action controllability. Generative modeling enables teleoperation, policy evaluation, and planning.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both describe negative feedback mechanisms preventing unsustainable extremes. Mechanism 1: resource exploitation creates depletion feedback (over-exploitation → stock collapse → forced reduction). Mechanism 2: leverage creates cost feedback (extreme positions → high funding costs → rebalancing → mean reversion). Structural match: economic feedback loops that regulate behavior by making extreme states economically unsustainable, preventing runaway dynamics through automatic stabilization.

paper_1.title: Untitled
paper_1.mechanism: Resource stock accumulates from production flow. Exploitation (flow out) versus conservation (stock maintenance) tradeoff. Maximum sustainable yield occurs at intermediate stock level. Over-exploitation depletes stock below replenishment threshold causing collapse.

paper_2.title: Untitled
paper_2.mechanism: Funding rates in perpetual futures impose economic costs on leveraged positions. High funding creates pressure to reduce directional exposure. Capital rebalancing occurs when funding costs exceed expected returns. Funding mechanisms act as negative feedback regulating trader behavior - extreme positions become economically unsustainable, creating mean-reverting pressure that defines trading ranges.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both describe learned adaptive resource allocation strategies. Mechanism 1: task difficulty creates phase transition in optimal strategy (gradual decay vs maintain-then-drop), threshold based on signal-to-noise ratio. Mechanism 2: entropy-based dual-signal allocation concentrates resources where information gain is highest (global: high-value samples, local: critical moments). Structural match: adaptive allocation based on informativeness/difficulty, with system learning to concentrate resources where they provide maximum learning value rather than distributing uniformly.

paper_1.title: Untitled
paper_1.mechanism: Phase transition in optimal strategy based on task difficulty regime. System exhibits qualitatively different behaviors (power decay vs warmup-stable-decay) separated by sharp threshold determined by ratio of signal learning rate to noise forgetting capacity. Easy-task regime benefits from gradual decay, hard-task regime requires maintaining peak resources until near completion.

paper_2.title: Untitled
paper_2.mechanism: Dual-signal adaptive resource allocation using entropy as proxy for learning value. Global level: relative entropy change identifies high-value samples for prioritized exploration. Local level: absolute entropy peaks identify critical moments within each trajectory. Concentrates computation where information gain is highest rather than uniform distribution.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both describe opinion evolution through multiple interacting processes operating at different scales. One emphasizes opinion-network coevolution with bidirectional feedback (opinions shape network, network shapes opinions), while the other emphasizes diffusion-convection-reaction coupling across local, global, and individual scales. Good structural match showing multi-scale coupling in opinion formation.

paper_1.title: Multi-level opinion dynamics with coupled processes
paper_1.mechanism: Individuals' opinions and network edge weights coevolve through coupled dynamics. Interaction strength depends on opinion distance. Similar opinions strengthen network connections. Connection strength amplifies opinion influence. This creates feedback between opinion convergence and network structure formation. Interaction function form determines emergent structures and stability.

paper_2.title: Multi-level opinion dynamics with coupled processes
paper_2.mechanism: Opinion evolution emerges from three coupled processes: diffusion (local influence spreading), convection (directional opinion flow driven by global trends), and reaction (endogenous opinion change). Each level operates at distinct scales—local peer-to-peer, global population-wide, and individual internal—that interact through multi-scale coupling. The system exhibits dynamics from interacting particle theory projected onto opinion space.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both describe how network position creates productivity advantages, but with important distinction between relational importance (routing, interaction frequency) and intrinsic causal importance. One emphasizes centrality creating complementarities, other reveals frequently-routed experts may have limited functional impact while sparsely-routed ones are causally critical. Good structural match showing surface vs deep network effects.

paper_1.title: Dual importance structure: relational vs causal influence
paper_1.mechanism: An agent's position in a collaboration network determines their productivity. Higher network centrality increases output through strategic complementarities with connected agents. Activity in one domain (scientific) enhances productivity in another domain (technological), but this effect is asymmetric - the reverse direction shows no detectable influence.

paper_2.title: Dual importance structure: relational vs causal influence
paper_2.mechanism: Expert importance exhibits dual structure: relational importance (routing frequency, interaction centrality) diverges from intrinsic importance (causal influence via gradient attribution). Frequently-routed experts may act as structural hubs with limited functional impact, while sparsely-routed experts can be causally critical. Masking intrinsically-important experts causes disproportionate collapse in interaction topology compared to masking frequent peers, revealing hidden causal dependencies.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both mechanisms describe dual-scope representation learning where systems must capture both context-invariant structure AND context-specific details simultaneously. M1 decomposes features into domain-invariant (shared across datasets) and domain-specific (private) components using mutual information optimization. M2 uses dual-head architecture to capture local pairwise regulatory logic and global cross-context expression patterns. Universal structure: complementary representations (shared-private or local-global) enable robust performance under distributional shift. Both use contrastive/mutual-information regularization to maintain separation between scopes while enabling knowledge transfer.

paper_1.title: Dual-scope representation: invariant vs specific
paper_1.mechanism: Feature disentanglement into domain-invariant and domain-specific components mitigates negative transfer in multi-dataset training. Cross-attention fusion adaptively models component interactions. Mutual information optimization maximizes domain-invariant consistency while minimizing domain-specific redundancy. Complementary shared-private representations enable knowledge transfer while preserving dataset-specific discriminability.

paper_2.title: Dual-scope representation: invariant vs specific
paper_2.mechanism: Dual-scope representation learning with contrastive regularization under distribution shift. System captures both local pairwise regulatory logic and global cross-context expression patterns via dual-head architecture. Contrastive learning enforces structural constraints in representation space, providing robustness against noise, sparsity, and cross-domain distributional shifts beyond what supervised signal alone provides.

verified_isomorphisms.structural_explanation: Both mechanisms describe how approaching criticality creates slow dynamics that qualitatively reorganize system behavior. M1: near bifurcation, convergence to steady state slows dramatically with relaxation time diverging according to universal scaling laws. M2: progressive coupling drives system toward infrared critical regime where spectral condensation creates extensive band of slow collective modes. Universal structure: criticality → emergence of slow timescales → qualitative transition in dynamics (not just degree). Both show transition from fast convergence (subcritical) to slow dynamics (critical) that reorganizes the entire system.

paper_1.title: Critical phenomena → slow dynamics
paper_1.mechanism: As a system approaches a bifurcation point, convergence to steady state slows dramatically. Near criticality, relaxation time diverges according to universal scaling laws. The system exhibits characteristic critical exponents that govern short-time behavior, asymptotic decay, and crossover between regimes.

paper_2.title: Critical phenomena → slow dynamics
paper_2.mechanism: Qualitative phase transition via spectral condensation at criticality. Progressive reentrant coupling drives system toward infrared critical regime where extensive band of slow collective modes emerges (spectral condensation), reorganizing dynamics qualitatively. Creates emergent capabilities absent at subcritical regime - transition in kind not degree, regardless of system scale.
